instruction: How does the research findings on the form of LIF spectral distribution and LoD values support the superiority of spectroscopic methods over traditional methods in identifying oil products and measuring ocean pollution volume?
Output:
The research findings on the form of Laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) spectral distribution and limit of detection (LoD) values support the superiority of spectroscopic methods over traditional methods in identifying oil products and measuring ocean pollution volume in several ways.

Firstly, the study found that the form of LIF spectral distribution changed depending on the state of the oil product (pure fuel, slick, or solution). This indicates that LIF spectroscopy can differentiate between different states of oil products, allowing for more accurate identification. Traditional methods, such as visual inspection or chemical analysis, may not be able to distinguish between different states of oil products as effectively.

Secondly, the research calibrated the LIF method for the most common types of heavy and light marine fuels. By establishing LoD values for each type, the study provides a quantitative measure of the sensitivity and accuracy of LIF spectroscopy in detecting oil pollution. This allows for more precise measurements of the volume of ocean pollution caused by bilge water disposal. In contrast, traditional methods may rely on subjective visual assessments or less sensitive analytical techniques, leading to less accurate measurements.

Additionally, the research investigated the time dynamics of the solution spectra and determined the time change features. This suggests that LIF spectroscopy can provide real-time monitoring of oil pollution
